theme: Investigation of erythema nodosum with a cough
questions:
A 28-year-old woman presents with a one-week history of multiple tender, erythematous nodules on both shins. She has also had a mild, dry cough for the last month. Examination is otherwise unremarkable.

Select the single most appropriate investigation from the options below.
notes:
Chest x-ray is the correct answer. Erythema nodosum is a panniculitis (inflammation of subcutaneous fat) that is often a reaction to an underlying systemic condition. Therefore, once the diagnosis is made clinically, the priority is to investigate for a trigger. A chest x-ray is a crucial first-line investigation in all patients presenting with erythema nodosum, regardless of respiratory symptoms. It is used to screen for two of the most important causes: sarcoidosis (which classically presents with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy) and tuberculosis. In this scenario, the patient's history of a persistent dry cough makes this investigation even more pertinent, as it could be a symptom of either of these conditions. Other potential findings on a chest x-ray could include lymphoma or other infections. Given the significant potential underlying pathologies, a chest x-ray is an essential part of the initial workup.

Throat swab is an incorrect choice. A throat swab for Group A streptococcus is a reasonable investigation in the workup of erythema nodosum, as streptococcal pharyngitis is one of the most common triggers, particularly in children and young adults. However, this patient's primary associated symptom is a cough, not a sore throat, making a respiratory pathology a higher priority to investigate first. While a subclinical streptococcal infection is possible, investigating the overt symptom of a cough with a chest x-ray takes precedence.

Skin biopsy is not the most appropriate next step. The clinical presentation of tender, erythematous nodules on the shins is classical for erythema nodosum, and the diagnosis can usually be made clinically. A skin biopsy is an invasive procedure and is typically reserved for cases where the diagnosis is uncertain or the lesions are atypical (e.g., ulcerating, located in unusual sites, or persistent). As the clinical picture here is typical, the focus should be on identifying the underlying cause rather than confirming the diagnosis histologically.

Faecal calprotectin is an incorrect option. Faecal calprotectin is a sensitive marker for intestinal inflammation and is used in the investigation of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), such as Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis. IBD is a well-recognised cause of erythema nodosum. However, this investigation is only indicated if there are accompanying gastrointestinal symptoms, such as diarrhoea, abdominal pain, or weight loss. This patient has no such symptoms, making this test low yield at this stage.

Antinuclear antibody (ANA) is not the most appropriate initial investigation. An ANA test is used to screen for autoimmune connective tissue diseases, such as Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). While skin manifestations can occur in these conditions, erythema nodosum is not a classic feature of SLE, and there are no other signs or symptoms in the history (e.g., photosensitive rash, arthritis, serositis) to suggest an underlying connective tissue disease. Therefore, this is not a primary investigation in the workup of isolated erythema nodosum.
question:
A 28-year-old woman presents with a one-week history of multiple tender, erythematous nodules on both shins. She has also had a mild, dry cough for the last month. Examination is otherwise unremarkable.

Select the single most appropriate investigation from the options below.

Chest x-ray is the correct answer. Erythema nodosum is a panniculitis (inflammation of subcutaneous fat) that is often a reaction to an underlying systemic condition. Therefore, this is not a primary investigation in the workup of isolated erythema nodosum.
title: Erythema nodosum
body:
Overview
  • inflammation of subcutaneous fat
  • typically causes tender, erythematous, nodular lesions
  • usually occurs over shins, may also occur elsewhere (e.g. forearms, thighs)
  • usually resolves within 6 weeks
  • lesions heal without scarring

Causes
  • infection
    • streptococci
    • tuberculosis
    • brucellosis
  • systemic disease
    • sarcoidosis
    • inflammatory bowel disease
    • Behcet's
  • malignancy/lymphoma
  • drugs
    • penicillins
    • sulphonamides
    • combined oral contraceptive pill
  • pregnancy

Investigation for underlying causes
  • chest x-ray (to assess for sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, other pulmonary infections, and lymphoma)
  • Throat swab for Group A strep
  • FBC, CRP
concept: Chest x-ray should be done in all patients with erythema nodosum
links:
DermNet NZ3217
Erythema nodosum

12490.concept_text: Chest x-ray should be done in all patients with erythema nodosum

questions: A 31-year-old female presents to the genitourinary medicine clinic due to four fleshy, protuberant lesions on her vulva which are slightly pigmented. She has recently started a relationship with a new partner. What is the most appropriate initial management?
notes:
The correct answer is Topical podophyllum. The patient's presentation is suggestive of genital warts, which are usually caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), specifically types 6 and 11. Topical podophyllum is a common first-line treatment for external genital warts in the UK as per British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) guidelines. It works by inhibiting cell division and thus causing death of the wart tissue.

Oral aciclovir would not be appropriate in this case, as it is an antiviral medication primarily used to treat herpes simplex virus infections, not HPV. While both are viral sexually transmitted infections, they have different pathophysiology and therefore require different treatments.

Topical salicylic acid is commonly used for treating non-genital warts such as those found on hands or feet. However, it's generally not recommended for use on sensitive areas like genitals because it can cause irritation and damage to surrounding healthy skin.

Topical aciclovir, similar to oral aciclovir, is mainly used for treating herpes simplex virus infections rather than HPV. Therefore, it wouldn't be effective in treating the patient's condition.

Finally, Electrocautery could potentially be used to remove genital warts but it's typically reserved for larger or more stubborn lesions that haven't responded to less invasive treatments. Additionally, it requires local or general anaesthesia and has a longer recovery time compared to topical treatments. As such, topical podophyllum would still be considered the most appropriate initial management in this case.

question_notes:
The correct answer is Topical podophyllum. The patient's presentation is suggestive of genital warts, which are usually caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), specifically types 6 and 11. Finally, Electrocautery could potentially be used to remove genital warts but it's typically reserved for larger or more stubborn lesions that haven't responded to less invasive treatments. Additionally, it requires local or general anaesthesia and has a longer recovery time compared to topical treatments. As such, topical podophyllum would still be considered the most appropriate initial management in this case.
title: Genital warts
body:
Genital warts (also known as condylomata accuminata) are a common cause of attendance at genitourinary clinics. They are caused by the many varieties of the human papillomavirus HPV, especially types 6 & 11. It is now well established that HPV (primarily types 16,18 & 33) predisposes to cervical cancer.

Features
  • small (2 - 5 mm) fleshy protuberances which are slightly pigmented
  • may bleed or itch

Management
  • topical podophyllum or cryotherapy are commonly used as first-line treatments depending on the location and type of lesion
    • multiple, non-keratinised warts are generally best treated with topical agents
    • solitary, keratinised warts respond better to cryotherapy
  • imiquimod is a topical cream that is generally used second line
  • genital warts are often resistant to treatment and recurrence is common although the majority of anogenital infections with HPV clear without intervention within 1-2 years
concept:
Genital wart treatment
  • multiple, non-keratinised warts: topical podophyllum
  • solitary, keratinised warts: cryotherapy
links:
British Association for Sexual Health and HIV84
United Kingdom National Guideline on the Management of Anogenital Warts
media:
Human papilloma virus
Osmosis - YouTube10

185.concept_text:
Genital wart treatment
   - multiple, non-keratinised warts: topical podophyllum
   - solitary, keratinised warts: cryotherapy

questions:
A 25-year-old female patient presents to the GP surgery with hearing loss. She reports that her hearing has been gradually declining to the point that it is now affecting her work as a secretary. She also complains of ringing in the left ear at times but denies pain or discharge from either ear. Her mother also has hearing loss at a young age but she's not sure what the cause was. You perform the following tests:

Weber testnot localising to either side

Right ear Left ear
Rinne testbone conduction >air conductionbone conduction > air conduction

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
The Weber and Rinne test showed a bilateral conductive hearing loss. This, in combination with the history of tinnitus and positive family history, points towards otosclerosis as the likely diagnosis.

Otitis media with effusion can also cause conductive hearing loss but typically there is a history of otitis media and more common in children.

Cerumen impaction can cause conductive hearing loss, however, given the positive family history, otosclerosis is more likely.

Cholesteatoma can cause conductive hearing loss but it does not fit with the bilateral hearing loss with a positive family history.

Stickler syndrome is a cause of sensorineural hearing loss.

Stickler syndrome is a cause of sensorineural hearing loss.
title: Otosclerosis
body:
Otosclerosis describes the replacement of normal bone by vascular spongy bone. It causes a progressive conductive deafness due to fixation of the stapes at the oval window. Otosclerosis is autosomal dominant and typically affects young adults

Onset is usually at 20-40 years - features include:
  • conductive deafness
  • tinnitus
  • tympanic membrane
    • the majority of patients will have a normal tympanic membrane
    • 10% of patients may have a 'flamingo tinge', caused by hyperaemia
  • positive family history

Management
  • hearing aid
  • stapedectomy
concept: Otosclerosis is characterised by conductive hearing loss, tinnitus and positive family history
links:
Patient.info121
Otosclerosis
media:
Understanding Otosclerosis
Zero To Finals - YouTube120

2956.concept_text: Otosclerosis is characterised by conductive hearing loss, tinnitus and positive family history

questions: A 23-year-old man comes to see his GP complaining of a sore knee for 1 week. On further questioning, he mentions that he has also had pain on urination and itchy, sore eyes. He has no past medical history and other than a stomach bug 2 weeks ago he is otherwise fit and well. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this man?
notes: The history is suggestive of acute reactive arthritis- 'can't see, can't pee, can't climb a tree/bend the knee'. As this is acute, the only of the treatment options that is appropriate is ibuprofen. Methotrexate and sulfasalazine can be used if the reactive arthritis becomes chronic. Steroids are an option, but intra-articular steroids are generally preferred than oral steroids, and the dose or oral steroids is much too high in this question.
question: A 23-year-old man comes to see his GP complaining of a sore knee for 1 week. On further questioning, he mentions that he has also had pain on urination and itchy, sore eyes. He has no past medical history and other than a stomach bug 2 weeks ago he is otherwise fit and well. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this man?
question_notes: The history is suggestive of acute reactive arthritis- 'can't see, can't pee, can't climb a tree/bend the knee'. As this is acute, the only of the treatment options that is appropriate is ibuprofen. Methotrexate and sulfasalazine can be used if the reactive arthritis becomes chronic. Steroids are an option, but intra-articular steroids are generally preferred than oral steroids, and the dose or oral steroids is much too high in this question.
title: Reactive arthritis
body:
Reactive arthritis is one of the HLA-B27 associated seronegative spondyloarthropathies. It encompasses what was formerly called Reiter's syndrome*, a term which described a classic triad of urethritis, conjunctivitis and arthritis following a dysenteric illness during the Second World War. Later studies identified patients who developed symptoms following a sexually transmitted infection (post-STI, now sometimes referred to as sexually acquired reactive arthritis, SARA).

Reactive arthritis is defined as an arthritis that develops following an infection where the organism cannot be recovered from the joint.

'Can't see, pee or climb a tree'

Epidemiology
  • post-STI form much more common in men (e.g. 10:1)
  • post-dysenteric form equal sex incidence

The table below shows the organisms that are most commonly associated with reactive arthritis:

Post-dysenteric formPost-STI form
Shigella flexneri
Salmonella typhimurium
Salmonella enteritidis
Yersinia enterocolitica
Campylobacter		Chlamydia trachomatis

Management
  • symptomatic: analgesia, NSAIDS, intra-articular steroids
  • sulfasalazine and methotrexate are sometimes used for persistent disease
  • symptoms rarely last more than 12 months

*as Reiter was a member of the Nazi party the term is no longer used
concept: Acute reactive arthritis can be treated with NSAIDs, as long as there are no contraindications
media:
Reactive arthritis
Zero to Finals - YouTube30
 
Reactive arthritis
Osmosis - YouTube10

3568.concept_text: Acute reactive arthritis can be treated with NSAIDs, as long as there are no contraindications

options: Face to face examination at the practice
Urgent admission to the emergency department for urgent CT head
questions:
A 40-year-old geography teacher has called his GP complaining of weakness in his left arm and leg that lasted for 1 hour this morning. This has now been completely resolved. He has no facial drooping, no residual weakness and no slurring of his voice. He explains to the GP that he feels 'as fit as a fiddle' and that he had only called on the insistence of his wife. He has a past medical history of a PE three months ago for which he takes apixaban.

What is the first-line management in this patient?
notes:
Urgent admission to the emergency department for urgent CT head - this is the correct answer because the patient is on apixaban and hence needs immediate imaging to exclude a haemorrhage. Once this has been excluded then a diagnosis of a TIA can be considered.

Calculate his HAS-BLED score - the purpose of a HAS-BLED score is to estimate the risk of major bleeding in patients taking anticoagulants for atrial fibrillation. This patient is taking an anticoagulant but not for atrial fibrillation so this score does not apply for this patient.

Face to face examination at the practice - although it can be useful to examine patients and obtain more information; this would delay the patients need for immediate imaging.

TIA clinic within 24 hours - this is incorrect because the patient is on a DOAC and hence needs immediate imaging. If he was not on an anticoagulant then this would be the correct answer.

TIA clinic within 7 days - this is incorrect because the patient is on a DOAC and hence needs immediate imaging. Previous NICE guidelines used the ABCD2 to identify patients that need to be seen within 24 hours and those that need to be seen within 7 days. This is no longer the case; all patients now need to be seen within 24 hours providing that they are not on an anticoagulant and do not have a bleeding disorder.

A 40-year-old geography teacher has called his GP complaining of weakness in his left arm and leg that lasted for 1 hour this morning. This has now been completely resolved. He has no facial drooping, no residual weakness and no slurring of his voice. He explains to the GP that he feels 'as fit as a fiddle' and that he had only called on the insistence of his wife. He has a past medical history of a PE three months ago for which he takes apixaban.

What is the first-line management in this patient?

Urgent admission to the emergency department for urgent CT head - this is the correct answer because the patient is on apixaban and hence needs immediate imaging to exclude a haemorrhage. Once this has been excluded then a diagnosis of a TIA can be considered.

Face to face examination at the practice - although it can be useful to examine patients and obtain more information; this would delay the patients need for immediate imaging.

TIA clinic within 24 hours - this is incorrect because the patient is on a DOAC and hence needs immediate imaging. If he was not on an anticoagulant then this would be the correct answer.

TIA clinic within 7 days - this is incorrect because the patient is on a DOAC and hence needs immediate imaging. Previous NICE guidelines used the ABCD2 to identify patients that need to be seen within 24 hours and those that need to be seen within 7 days. This is no longer the case; all patients now need to be seen within 24 hours providing that they are not on an anticoagulant and do not have a bleeding disorder.
title: Transient ischaemic attack
body:
A transient ischaemic attack (TIA), as the name suggests, is a brief period of neurological deficit due to a vascular cause, typically lasting less than an hour. The National Clinical Guideline for Stroke was published in 2023 and made a number of updated recommendations, including the use of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT). It should be noted that DAPT is not currently recommended for 'major' ischaemic stroke as the risk of haemorrhagic transformation is too high.

The original definition of a TIA was time-based: a sudden onset of a focal neurologic symptom and/or sign lasting less than 24 hours, brought on by a transient decrease in blood flow. However, this has now changed as it is recognised that even short periods of ischaemia can result in pathological changes to the brain. Therefore, a new 'tissue-based' definition is now used: a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction caused by focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischaemia, without acute infarction. REF

Patients often use the term 'mini-stroke' for TIAs.

Clinical features

The clinical features are similar to those of a stroke, i.e. sudden onset, focal neurological deficit but, rather than persisting, the features resolve, typically within 1 hour.

Possible features include
  • unilateral weakness or sensory loss.
  • aphasia or dysarthria
  • ataxia, vertigo, or loss of balance
  • visual problems
    • sudden transient loss of vision in one eye (amaurosis fugax)
    • diplopia
    • homonymous hemianopia

Assessment and referral

Patients with acute focal neurological symptoms that resolve completely within 24 hours of onset (i.e. suspected TIA) should:
  • be given aspirin 300 mg immediately unless contraindicated
  • assessed urgently within 24 hours by a stroke specialist clinician

Examples of TIA mimics that require exclusion
  • hypoglycaemia
  • intracranial haemorrhage
    • all patients on anticoagulants or with similar risk factors should be admitted for urgent imaging to exclude haemorrhage

If a patient presents more than 7 days ago they should be seen by a stroke specialist clinician as soon as possible within 7 days.

The ABCD2 prognostic score has previously been used to risk stratify patients who present with a suspected TIA. However, data from studies have suggested it performs poorly and it is therefore no longer recommended.

Patients with suspected TIA should be assessed by a stroke specialist clinician before a decision on brain imaging NICE
  • NICE recommend that CT brains should not be done 'unless there is clinical suspicion of an alternative diagnosis that CT could detect'
    • an example exception would be when there is a concern about haemorrhage as the patient is taking anticoagulants
  • MRI (including diffusion-weighted and blood-sensitive sequences) is preferred to determine the territory of ischaemia, or to detect haemorrhage or alternative pathologies
    • it should be done on the same day as the specialist assessment if possible

Management of TIA

It should be remembered that patients who've had a TIA are at high risk of further vascular events, particularly in the first few days. This section covers management following a diagnosis, i.e. after being seen by a stroke specialist clinician.

Medication

Immediate antithrombotic therapy: REF
  • patients with TIA or minor ischaemic stroke should be given antiplatelet therapy provided there is neither a contraindication nor a high risk of bleeding
  • for patients within 24 hours of onset of TIA or minor ischaemic stroke and with a low risk of bleeding, the following DAPT regimes should be considered:
    • clopidogrel (initial dose 300 mg followed by 75 mg od) + aspirin (initial dose 300 mg followed by 75 mg od for 21 days) followed by monotherapy with clopidogrel 75 mg od
    • ticagrelor + clopidogrel is an alternative
  • if not appropriate for DAPT:
    • clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose followed by 75 mg od should be given
  • proton pump inhibitor therapy should be considered for DAPT

The different antithrombotic recommendations may seem confusing - it is helpful to think of 3 different phases for a typical patient:

Resolved TIA symptoms, awaiting specialist review within 24 hoursReviewed by specialist, initial 21 days when at high risk of further eventsLong-term secondary prevention after 21 days
AspirinAspirin + ClopidogrelClopidogrel

If a patient has atrial fibrillation they should be anticoagulated as soon as intracranial haemorrhage has been excluded.

Lipid modification
  • high-intensity statin (such as atorvastatin 20-80 mg daily) - the aim of statin therapy is to reduce non-HDL cholesterol by more than 40%

Further investigation

Carotid imaging
  • atherosclerosis in the carotid artery may be a source of emboli in some patients
  • patients who are considered candidates for carotid intervention should have carotid imaging performed within 24 hours of assessment
    • carotid duplex ultrasound or either CT angiography or MR angiography
  • carotid endarterectomy is recommend if the patient has suffered a stroke or TIA in the carotid territory and is not severely disabled NICE
    • should only be considered if the stenosis > 50% according to North American Symptomatic Carotid Endarterectomy Trial (NASCET) criteria
+ it should be noted that previous guidelines have used other reporting methods, that have resulted in different cut-offs, e.g. European Carotid Surgery Trial (ECST) with a cut-off of 70%
  • it should be performed as soon as possible within 7 days
concept: If a patient is on warfarin/a DOAC/ or has a bleeding disorder and they are suspected of having a TIA, they should be admitted immediately for imaging to exclude a haemorrhage
links:
RCP1325
2016 Stroke guidelines


National Clinical Guideline for Stroke1110
2023 National Clinical Guideline for Stroke


NICE166
2019 Stroke and transient ischaemic attack in over 16s: diagnosis and initial management


Radiopaedia112
Transient ischaemic attack
media:
Understanding Carotid Artery Stenosis
Zero To Finals - YouTube44

279.concept_text:
Antiplatelets
   - TIA: clopidogrel
   - ischaemic stroke: clopidogrel

3993.concept_text: Hypoglycaemia can lead to focal neurological symptoms and needs to be ruled out as a mimic of TIA

4061.concept_text: If a patient is on warfarin/a DOAC/ or has a bleeding disorder and they are suspected of having a TIA, they should be admitted immediately for imaging to exclude a haemorrhage

9800.concept_text: The definition of a TIA is now tissue-based, not time-based: a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction caused by focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischaemia, without acute infarction

11530.concept_text: All TIA patients should have an urgent carotid doppler unless they are not a candidate for carotid endarterectomy

12217.concept_text: Patients with a TIA or minor ischaemic stroke who present within 24 hours, and with a low risk of bleeding, should be given DAPT (e.g. clopidogrel + aspirin)

questions:
A 68-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with one week of worsening fever and productive cough with green sputum. He reports having seen his GP two days prior and having a course of antibiotics. He has a past medical history of COPD and recurrent chest infections.

On examination, left-sided basal crackles are audible on auscultation of the chest. Observations are normal except for a temperature of 38.1ºC. As part of the clerking, a routine ECG is performed, which shows a PR interval of 120ms and a corrected QT interval of 480ms.

What antibiotic is he most likely to have taken?
notes:
This patient is likely to have had pneumonia. Numerous drugs are associated with prolonging the QT interval, which has been detected incidentally on a routine ECG. Typically, over 440ms in men and over 460ms in women is considered prolonged. A QT interval over 500ms is associated with developing Torsades de Pointes. Of the various antibiotic classes, macrolides are most strongly associated with QT prolongation, making clarithromycin the correct answer.

Amoxicillin is incorrect. This is a penicillin derivative commonly used in the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia for stable patients. However, it is not associated with QT prolongation.

Co-amoxiclav is incorrect. This antibiotic is commonly used in the treatment of community and hospital-acquired pneumonia in either oral or intravenous preparations, depending on clinical severity. However, it is not associated with QT prolongation.

Doxycycline is incorrect. It is commonly used orally in the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia - typically in patients with penicillin allergies. However, as a tetracycline, it is not commonly associated with QT prolongation.

Phenoxymethylpenicillin is incorrect. This is not associated with QT prolongation, nor is it typically used for chest infections. Rather, it is commonly used in the management of bacterial tonsillitis.
question:
A 68-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with one week of worsening fever and productive cough with green sputum. He reports having seen his GP two days prior and having a course of antibiotics. He has a past medical history of COPD and recurrent chest infections.

On examination, left-sided basal crackles are audible on auscultation of the chest. Observations are normal except for a temperature of 38.1ºC. As part of the clerking, a routine ECG is performed, which shows a PR interval of 120ms and a corrected QT interval of 480ms.

What antibiotic is he most likely to have taken?
question_notes:
This patient is likely to have had pneumonia. Numerous drugs are associated with prolonging the QT interval, which has been detected incidentally on a routine ECG. Typically, over 440ms in men and over 460ms in women is considered prolonged. A QT interval over 500ms is associated with developing Torsades de Pointes. Of the various antibiotic classes, macrolides are most strongly associated with QT prolongation, making clarithromycin the correct answer.

Amoxicillin is incorrect. This is a penicillin derivative commonly used in the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia for stable patients. However, it is not associated with QT prolongation.

Co-amoxiclav is incorrect. This antibiotic is commonly used in the treatment of community and hospital-acquired pneumonia in either oral or intravenous preparations, depending on clinical severity. However, it is not associated with QT prolongation.

Doxycycline is incorrect. It is commonly used orally in the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia - typically in patients with penicillin allergies. However, as a tetracycline, it is not commonly associated with QT prolongation.

Phenoxymethylpenicillin is incorrect. This is not associated with QT prolongation, nor is it typically used for chest infections. Rather, it is commonly used in the management of bacterial tonsillitis.
title: Macrolides
body:
Erythromycin was the first macrolide used clinically. Newer examples include clarithromycin and azithromycin.

Macrolides act by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis by blocking translocation. If pushed to give an answer they are bacteriostatic in nature, but in reality this depends on the dose and type of organism being treated.

Mechanism of resistance
  • post-transcriptional methylation of the 23S bacterial ribosomal RNA

Adverse effects
  • prolongation of the QT interval
  • gastrointestinal side-effects are common. Nausea is less common with clarithromycin than erythromycin
  • cholestatic jaundice: risk may be reduced if erythromycin stearate is used
  • P450 inhibitor (see below)
  • azithromycin is associated with hearing loss and tinnitus

Common interactions
  • statins should be stopped whilst taking a course of macrolides. Macrolides inhibit the cytochrome P450 isoenzyme CYP3A4 that metabolises statins. Taking macrolides concurrently with statins significantly increases the risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis.
concept: Macrolides may cause prolongation of the QT interval

5560.concept_text: Macrolide antibiotics are potent inhibitors of cytochrome P450 enzymes and may elevate the INR if co-prescribed with warfarin

10946.concept_text: Macrolides may cause prolongation of the QT interval

instruction: For each of the following scenarios please select the most appropriate treatment:
questions: A farmer is admitted with suspected  organophosphate insecticide poisoning
Z lzm hr zclhssdc enkknvhmf zm nudqcnrd ne hqnm szakdsr
Zm zkbngnkhb lzm hr aqntfgs sn sgd Dldqfdmbx Cdozqsldms. Ghr eqhdmc rzxr gd gzr cqtmj svn ansskdr ne zmsheqddyd
question: A farmer is admitted with suspected  organophosphate insecticide poisoning
title: Organophosphate insecticide poisoning
body:
One of the effects of organophosphate poisoning is inhibition of acetylcholinesterase leading to upregulation of nicotinic and muscarinic cholinergic neurotransmission. In warfare, sarin gas is a highly toxic synthetic organophosphorus compound that has similar effects.

Features can be predicted by the accumulation of acetylcholine (mnemonic = SLUD)
  • Salivation
  • Lacrimation
  • Urination
  • Defecation/diarrhoea
  • cardiovascular: hypotension, bradycardia
  • also: small pupils, muscle fasciculation

Management
  • atropine
  • the role of pralidoxime is still unclear - meta-analyses to date have failed to show any clear benefit

questions:
An 86-year-old gentleman comes to see you with his daughter, for a medication review. His memory has been declining recently and he was referred to memory clinic three months ago, where he was diagnosed with Alzheimer's dementia.

His other medical history includes osteoporosis, ischaemic heart disease and atrial fibrillation. In view of his dementia, which one of the following medications should you consider stopping?
notes:
There are multiple causes of dementia as outlined below, the majority of which are progressive and irreversible. There are medications that can be used to slow progression, but as clinicians we also have a responsibility to ensure that our patients aren't taking medications which may make things worse.

The STOPP-START Criteria (Gallagher et al., 2008) outlines medications that we should consider withdrawing in the elderly. One example of this is the use of tricyclic antidepressants in patients with dementia, due to the risk of worsening cognitive impairment.
question:
An 86-year-old gentleman comes to see you with his daughter, for a medication review. His memory has been declining recently and he was referred to memory clinic three months ago, where he was diagnosed with Alzheimer's dementia.

His other medical history includes osteoporosis, ischaemic heart disease and atrial fibrillation. In view of his dementia, which one of the following medications should you consider stopping?
question_notes:
There are multiple causes of dementia as outlined below, the majority of which are progressive and irreversible. There are medications that can be used to slow progression, but as clinicians we also have a responsibility to ensure that our patients aren't taking medications which may make things worse.

The STOPP-START Criteria (Gallagher et al., 2008) outlines medications that we should consider withdrawing in the elderly. One example of this is the use of tricyclic antidepressants in patients with dementia, due to the risk of worsening cognitive impairment.
title: Dementia
body:
Dementia is a clinical syndrome of progressive cognitive impairment that affects daily function and independence. It is thought to affect over 900,000 people in the UK and accounts for a large amount of health and social care spending. The most common cause of dementia in the UK is Alzheimer's disease, followed by vascular dementia and Lewy body dementia. These conditions may coexist.

Features
  • diagnosis can be difficult and is often delayed
  • assessment tools recommended by NICE for the non-specialist setting include: 10-point cognitive screener (10-CS), 6-Item cognitive impairment test (6CIT)
  • assessment tools not recommended by NICE for the non-specialist setting include the abbreviated mental test score (AMTS), general practitioner assessment of cognition (GPCOG) and the mini-mental state examination (MMSE). However, these have been widely used historically. An MMSE score of 24 or less out of 30 suggests dementia

Management
  • in primary care, a blood screen is usually sent to exclude reversible causes (e.g. Hypothyroidism). NICE recommend the following tests: FBC, U&E, LFTs, calcium, glucose, ESR/CRP, TFTs, vitamin B12 and folate levels
  • in secondary care, neuroimaging is performed* to exclude other reversible conditions (e.g. subdural haematoma, normal pressure hydrocephalus) and to help provide information on aetiology, guiding prognosis and management
    • according to the 2018 NICE guidelines, structural imaging should be offered to help exclude reversible causes of cognitive decline and to assist with subtype diagnosis unless dementia is well established and the subtype is clear
  • patients are now commonly referred to memory clinics, which are often led by old-age psychiatrists or geriatricians
links:
NICE1313
2018 Dementia guidelines
media:
Understanding Dementia (Alzheimer's & Vascular & Frontotemporal & Lewy Body Dementia)
Rhesus Medicine - YouTube21

448.concept_text: Neuroimaging is required to diagnose dementia

questions:
Maria, an 11-year-old girl, has been rushed to the Children's Assessment Unit with a potential seizure. Her dad filmed the episode and show's you a video in which she has clonic, jerking movements that initially begin in her hand and then move proximally up the arm.

In what type of epilepsy is this presentation usually seen?
notes:
Jacksonian movements are a feature of frontal lobe epilepsy.

Temporal lobe seizures are associated with aura, lip smacking and clothes plucking.

Occipital seizures are associated with visual abnormalities.

Parietal seizures are associated with sensory abnormalities.

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is a genetic generalised epilepsy syndrome including absence, myoclonic and generalised tonic-clonic seizures.
question:
Maria, an 11-year-old girl, has been rushed to the Children's Assessment Unit with a potential seizure. Her dad filmed the episode and show's you a video in which she has clonic, jerking movements that initially begin in her hand and then move proximally up the arm.

In what type of epilepsy is this presentation usually seen?
question_notes:
Jacksonian movements are a feature of frontal lobe epilepsy.

Temporal lobe seizures are associated with aura, lip smacking and clothes plucking.

Occipital seizures are associated with visual abnormalities.

Parietal seizures are associated with sensory abnormalities.

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is a genetic generalised epilepsy syndrome including absence, myoclonic and generalised tonic-clonic seizures.
title: Epilepsy: localising features of focal seizures
body:
LocationTypical seizure type
Temporal lobeMay occur with or without impairment of consciousness or awareness

An aura occurs in most patients
  • typically a rising epigastric sensation
  • also psychic or experiential phenomena, such as dejÃ  vu, jamais vu
  • less commonly hallucinations (auditory/gustatory/olfactory)

Seizures typically last around one minute
  • automatisms (e.g. lip smacking/grabbing/plucking) are common
Frontal lobe (motor)Head/leg movements, posturing, post-ictal weakness, Jacksonian march
Parietal lobe (sensory)Paraesthesia
Occipital lobe (visual)Floaters/flashes
concept: Jacksonian movement (clonic movements travelling proximally) indicates frontal lobe epilepsy
media:
Epilepsy (generalized, focal) - simple, complex, tonic, clonic, causes, symptoms
Osmosis - YouTube62

8567.concept_text: Jacksonian movement (clonic movements travelling proximally) indicates frontal lobe epilepsy

questions: Which of the following is associated with a good prognosis in rheumatoid arthritis?
notes:
The correct answer is Rheumatoid factor negative. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic, systemic inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the synovial joints. The presence of rheumatoid factor (RF) in patients with RA is generally associated with a more severe disease course, including higher rates of joint erosions and extra-articular manifestations. Therefore, being RF-negative can be associated with a milder disease course and thus a better prognosis.

HLA DR4 is incorrect as it is associated with susceptibility to RA rather than its prognosis. HLA-DR4 positive individuals have been found to be at an increased risk of developing RA but its presence does not necessarily indicate the severity or prognosis of the disease.

Anti-CCP antibodies are also related to the diagnosis of RA rather than its prognosis. Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are highly specific for RA and can be present years before the onset of clinical symptoms. However, similar to RF, their presence has been linked with more severe disease progression and poorer outcomes.

Rheumatoid nodules, which are firm subcutaneous nodules that often develop in areas subjected to pressure, are typically associated with more severe disease and hence do not indicate a good prognosis in RA. They are most commonly found in patients who are also RF-positive.

Finally, an insidious onset does not necessarily predict a good prognosis in RA. While it's true that a slower onset might delay diagnosis and treatment initiation, this doesn't translate into better long-term outcomes. In fact, early aggressive treatment regardless of onset speed has been shown to improve long-term outcomes by preventing irreversible joint damage.

question_notes:

title: Rheumatoid arthritis: prognostic features
body:
A number of features have been shown to predict a poor prognosis in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, as listed below

Poor prognostic features
  • rheumatoid factor positive
  • anti-CCP antibodies
  • poor functional status at presentation
  • X-ray: early erosions (e.g. after < 2 years)
  • extra articular features e.g. nodules
  • HLA DR4
  • insidious onset


In terms of gender there seems to be a split in what the established sources state is associated with a poor prognosis. However both the American College of Rheumatology and the recent NICE guidelines (which looked at a huge number of prognosis studies) seem to conclude that female gender is associated with a poor prognosis.
links:
NICE34
2018 Rheumatoid arthritis guidelines
